docs.title: My Deets

docs.text: DevOps as Cultural Movement and Historical Moment There's a bit to unpack here. The following words are just my thoughts as observer and student. Perez and Gouldner These are my personal thoughts about the DevOps cultural movement. More specifically as it relates to two things: Dr. Carlota Perez's Age of Software and the ascendence of Dr. Alvin Gouldners's New Class in Late Capitalism(1). The DevOps Cultural Movement I speak specifically about the DevOps cultural movement (2), as envisioned by the original adopters reference not tooling or even the many aspects that the term may engender. I learned these things as an extremely fortunate connection to one of the greatest minds in the industry. More on this later. Intro A little about me. I was a Sociology/Cultural Anthropology/Music i.e. conservatory composition student/musician at an art school filled with amazing musicians, artists, poets, writers and all kinds of cool humans Interestingly enough Uni is a place where these interactions occur seemingly organically. I think this experience makes one yearn for this later in life. When I find a gig with all kinds of folks, languages, shapes, looks, sounds of dialects, FOOD DISCOVERIES, it makes me feel at home. Diversity is our natural state having varience is the most healthy thing. It's absence is sickly. Cutural Anthropology, Critical Social Theory and Sociology of It was in this conext that I was studying Cultural Anthopology and Sociology and studying Critical Social Theory while being a TA for my professor, Dr. Jeffrey Halley. I briefly studied the Sociology of Technology and attended some graduate classes with Dr. Henry Eskowitcz. I had the good fortune of Prof Louis Amdur as a transformative influence as an advisor. The fusion of Cultural Anthopology, Critical Social Theory and Sociology would be the introduction to many mind-blowing ideas; touchstones that would further inform my frame of DevOps as a cultural movement. As a senior project, I obsessed over Towards a Political Econoomy of The New Class . It was here that I started to understand attributes of the cultue of critical discourse and the New Class. It was the Critical Social theory part is where I realized how it creates a natural and beneficial symmetry around the economic imperitives of market demadeds. In some ways, Amazon's being customer obsessed_ it the ultimate triumph of this capitalist spirit_ As I learned more about DevOps and saw it's incorporation into the and just as importantly a historical moment. before cooptation and cultural hegemony. Westrum and Goulner (Broader comparisons and allignemnts between Gouldner and Ron Westrum go here) DevOps as Cultural Hedgemony - When Edwards/Humble inserted Lean into the CAMS acronym CA(L)MS (Edwards/Willis DevOps Cafe'), it embeded a visible expression; a self-awareness of Lean as intrinsticly part of DevOps; an acknoledgement of the agile admin practices as prime-mover. This alone would not necessarily create the adoption that the transformed the industry and ,arguably history, dramatically. That would require something bigger; more than just a way of working and tooling. Enter DevOpsDays DevOpsDays as Cultural Phenomena Flywheel of Cultural Adoption: Local, grass-roots and fusion of commerce and cultural affinities (ways of working). Small is beautiful local optimization global reach _ It is with this a way of working seeing Ideology DevOps and SRE as Cultural Identifier When tribal knowledge is discussed in tech, it discribes an understood Kaizen and the Culture of Critical Discourse I'd argue the self-awareness of culture in CALMS is an expression of New Class Ideals of culture and behavior modificaton as an expression 1. This was introduced to me by Dr Mik Kersten and his insightful book Project to Product Described as such for me by Adam Jacob at Velocity '11 closing keynote. Him holding up the No Asshole Rule as model. Chef's kiss*

docs.text: A little about me. I was a Sociology/Cultural Anthropology/Music i.e. conservatory composition student/musician at an art school filled with amazing musicians, artists, poets, writers and all kinds of cool humans Interestingly enough Uni is a place where these interactions occur seemingly organically. I think this experience makes one yearn for this later in life. When I find a gig with all kinds of folks, languages, shapes, looks, sounds of dialects, FOOD DISCOVERIES, it makes me feel at home. Diversity is our natural state having varience is the most healthy thing. It's absence is sickly.
docs.title: Intro

docs.text: It was in this conext that I was studying Cultural Anthopology and Sociology and studying Critical Social Theory while being a TA for my professor, Dr. Jeffrey Halley. I briefly studied the Sociology of Technology and attended some graduate classes with Dr. Henry Eskowitcz. I had the good fortune of Prof Louis Amdur as a transformative influence as an advisor. The fusion of Cultural Anthopology, Critical Social Theory and Sociology would be the introduction to many mind-blowing ideas; touchstones that would further inform my frame of DevOps as a cultural movement. As a senior project, I obsessed over Towards a Political Econoomy of The New Class . It was here that I started to understand attributes of the cultue of critical discourse and the New Class. It was the Critical Social theory part is where I realized how it creates a natural and beneficial symmetry around the economic imperitives of market demadeds. In some ways, Amazon's being customer obsessed_ it the ultimate triumph of this capitalist spirit_ As I learned more about DevOps and saw it's incorporation into the and just as importantly a historical moment. before cooptation and cultural hegemony.

This alone would not necessarily create the adoption that the transformed the industry and ,arguably history, dramatically. That would require something bigger; more than just a way of working and tooling. Enter DevOpsDays
